Supreme Court to weigh late-term abortions
 Newly constituted court plunges into contentious issue
 
 Updated: 10:30 a.m. ET Feb. 21, 2006
 WASHINGTON - The Supreme Court said Tuesday it will consider the constitutionality of banning a type of late-term abortion, teeing up a contentious issue for a newly-constituted court already in a state of flux over privacy rights.
 
 The Bush administration has pressed the high court to reinstate the federal law, passed in 2003 but never put in effect because it was struck down by judges in California, Nebraska and New York.

 Well, the law in question limits itself explicitly to "Any physiciain who, in or affecting interstate or foreign commerce..." Here's a link to the actual bill for easy access. So, it is not even necessarily the case that Congress has banned all partial birth abortions, just the ones performed by a physician affecting interstate or foreign commerce.
